lg.l: ATtend Malicious S────t Si vous plait,, attend, To what I go to say.le vous prie Monsieur S──t sometime the D──r,
le dis
Permit me now to draw my Raper.
O D──n I burst, nor can, nor will refrain,
I'll write, let others in their turn complain;Taiser, taiser vous! My tormented Ear,
Less dreads a Pillory, then Phamphleteer;
I've heard myself to death and plagu'd each Hour,
Shan't I return the Vengeance in my Pow'r?
For who can write the true Absurd like Me?Ils par donnent D──r? que I'entend but thee?S────t, if like mine or D──r were they Stile,
The Blood of Vipers had not stain'd thy File;
Merit less solid, less despite had bred,
They had not bit, and then they had not bled.
There are who say no Man can be a Wit,
Unless for Newgate or for Bedlam fit.
You scurrilous abusive SATYR write,
You think to shew a Genius, yet a Spite;
Your lasting Works will ne'er be reckon'd good,
Till you have been where Curl the Printer stood.
Alas! poor me, you may soon my Fortune guess,
I write, and yet Humanity profess.
Some write confin'd by Physick, some by Debt,
Some, for it's Sunday, some because 'tis Wet,
But you thro' private Pique do the publick Right,
And love your King and Country out of Spight,
You strive to write, because your Father writ,
And prove yourself un-B────d by your Wit.C'est bien you have made so dextrous Shift,
I'entend, you J──────n, viz. D────n S────t, you St. P──────'s saucy D──n,
Et Aussi
With Silver Verge and Surplice clean;
Of Ox──────d, or of Or──────d's Grace,
In looser Rhyme did beg Jadis a Place;
A Place you have got, you clyp'd a Stall,
And eke a thousand Pounds withal;
You might, Aussi bien, have got a Miter,
Had not you been a scurrilous Writer. who's the facetious Man,
le vous prie S──t
That with you en Famille are Cup and Can;
Or Comment S'appillent ils that's tete a tete,, and Dish of Meat;Pardonnez moi? I shou'd have said,
At unverre du Vin
At round Cake of stail Ginger-Bread., how do you take Delight,
Montrez moi? S──t
In silly scribling thus, out of mere Spight;
Because you have not had your Will,
To spleen and scandal you have shap'd your Quil,
Against M──────rs, V──────y's and both K────,
I'espere, you have broke one of your Strings;
Or that your Lyar is out of Order,
'Fraid lest you must attend the R──────r;
Then adieu, S──t, your Speech will falter,Il est Vray, long since you deserv'd a H────.
Since yet, Vous etes bien, S──t, say no more,Nous tous Scavons, you are the Son of a ────.
For tho' no great Connoisseur, I make a Shift,
To find out another from a S────t.
